comment.author: 58351357@N08
comment._content:
Wow!  

Note to architects - as well as being functionally efficient and easy to use, this person makes an effort to visit and use libraries which are beautiful spaces to be in.  If I ever get to Dublin, this will definitely be on my list of places to visit!

comment._content: Now that's what I call a library! Not one of the horrible, antiseptic, characterless and featureless places that seem to be trying to put you off reading for life we see nowadays.

comment._content: There once was a chap from Glenageary. Who worked on the Liverpool Ferry. But, in his spare time, Without reason or rhyme, walked tightrope in the Trinity Library.

comment.author: 59890603@N07
comment._content:
To me this is what paradise looks like.
I'd love to build a virtual 3D reconstruction of this so people could visit it online and walk around it, like I've done with 1920s Berlin.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: You might like to see this then [http://www.flickr.com/photos/1920sberlin] from Darren McLoughlin at Dublin Photo Tours. It's a 360 degree panorama of the Long Room...

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] OH MY GOD!
I have a facebook album I call 'Paradise', full of pictures where you can lock me up for the rest of my life and I wouldn't mind.
Deserted islands, beautiful old castles, tiny villages in the highlands... and the long room!
Thank you for that link!
Paradise indeed.

comment.author: 79216223@N05
comment._content: I'm currently doing research on 'social space' on a university campus where libraries are being refurbished, and spankingly smart new ones built - I think yours is wonderful -why can't we have that, instead of blank white and glass, brightness and tinny mp3 'beats' everywhere? Give me dust, lovely old book smell, and the shuffle of papers anyday.
